Peter Cullinan wrote:

> 
> I want to know what is the most efficient way of testing the connection
> pools.  At the moment I am thinking of using Mike Clarkes JUnitPerf, is this
> the correct road to go on.  And if it is then, has anybody got any tips to
> implement the test.

 >

Ideally, software under load should exhibit constant latency (response 
time) and linear throughput regardless of the load level. 
Realistically, software under various degrees of load should scale to 
exhibit low latency and high throughput as necessary for the application.

With JUnitPerf, you can generate a simulated load by decorating an 
existing test as a LoadTest.  The LoadTest is useful to help verify that 
the decorated test produces the expected results under various load 
levels.  A LoadTest can then be decorated with a TimedTest to 
automatically check that the load test meets an expected latency.

There are a number of good load testing tools on the market, and 
JUnitPerf doesn't attempt to match their features.  Rather, JUnitPerf is 
intended to be used to keep an automatic check on expected results 
response times in the spirit of relentless refactoring and testing.
